than ours really seemed to have a good time.
It had been drizzling
all morning and no planes came in but after lunch the ceiling lifted a
bit and planes started landing.
Mr. Pahlevi and I were walking away
from the luncheon when we were approached by two foreign army
officers
all covered with ribbons and decorations.
As they neared us they hit the
rain soaked side walk and drawled on their stomachs.
He turned
to me
and quite simply
said "Mr. Bixby, I am the Shah of Iran travelling
incognito.
guard.
This, pointing to the
two prostrate generals, is my body
I'm sure
glad they couldn't get here any sooner,
I've had a wonderful
time."
If we had gone to Teheran I would have tried to contact Mr. Pahlevi
for I'm sure he would have remembered the incident.
Mon. Dec. 7.
The
En route Karachi.
Wedre rather sad
to be leaving Beirut.
Intercontinental (Pan Am) Hotel is most comfortable, the service
perfect and
the staff most friendly and happy.
Our room on the 8th floor
had a room wide balcony with a splendid view of the whole city, the busy
harbor and
the snow covered mountains to the east.
Every morning we get
the N.Y. Times or Herald Tribune Paris air mail edition of
the day before
with complete market quotations even seldom traded shares,
the American
exchange
and on Mondays even the unlisted dogs.
It would
be awfully easy
to spend a winter in Beirut.
We arrived Karachi after asmooth four hour
flight, stayed at the pirport for a half hour and were off for a 2} hour
flight to Dum Dum airport, Calcutta.
That brought back the war days when
Bondy was doing such a magnificent gey job of directing CNAC operations over
the hump.
As I write this we have just landed in brilliant sun shine at
Rangoon.
Its now 6:15 a.. Beirut time but 10:45 a.m. local time and when
we get to Hong Kong we'll have to move our watches back six hours.
We
"Time"
trouble on all our trips.
Bangkok.
Field was covered with American transports, pursuit ships and
bombers withthe bomb racks loaded.
They are here of course to
back up
our forces in Viet Nam.
Incidentally our course from Bangkok to Hong Kong
goes right over where most of the fighting is going on.
I hope the Commies
have not decided
to make an "incident" out of this flight.
Later...
They had not
I'm sure I should have told my younger readers that lex Barker was very
much in evidence around our hotel.
For the benefit of you oldsters he is
a sort of Tarzan character.
Also had Mickey Rooney, David Niven and some
others around mostly very dizzie blondes who have yet to make a name.
We arrived Hong Kong late in the afternoon in perfect visibility
and
were both amazed at what has happened to
the Crown Colony,
since we last
saw it.
I can't even begin to describe it.
I suppose that no where else
in the
whole world is there such a concentratint of people. One huge
apartment complex after another, something like those big housing develop=
ments in New York.
You know Hong Kong Colony is really made up of the Island
of Victoria and a small peninsula on the mainland called Kowloon.
The
latter plus the island were deeded outright to the British by the Chinese.
Then there is the
"leased territory" about 10 miles square back of Kowloon
which is leased to the British until 1997.
Most of the new buildings
have been put up on the "owned" areas.
When we lived in Hong Kohg the
population was around one million with probably 75% of that on Victoria
Island.
Now the population is just under four million with 70% on
mainland and 30% on the island.
The government of Hong Kong has built
many huge apartments for the refugees who used to squat wherever they could.
These
"apartments"
are walk up mostly six stories high, some ten, with rooms
much like a honeycomb.
Toilet and bath facilities are at the ends of the floors
